Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Dear Anonymous, Thanks for your message. In week 5, 6 and 7, we treat statistical physics, of the same type as in week 1 (for random walks) and week 2 - 4 (for classical particles), but now for quantum particles, as they are all around us. This will lead us from a discussion of a quantum particle in a harmonic oscillator to a discussion of path-sampling methods, to a discussion of Bose-Einstein condensation, as we announced it a long time ago. There is nothing to be afraid about, and generations of students, who were not experts in quantum physics went through these presentations. Just accept that in Quantum physics, particles are described by wavefunctions (this, everybody has heard about). Also accept that these wavefunctions can be computed (for the harmonic oscillator) by the harmonic wavefunction.py. Finally accept that the square of the wavefunction Psi(x) Psi(x)* gives the probability of a particle to be at Then, let yourself be guided through a selection of topics. It is definitely NOT true that our discussion of density matrices is only for cognoscenti... people who already know everything. Students all over the world learn quantum physics without ever hearing about density matrices. If they hear about them, it gets very very abstract, although it isn't. So just take my word about it that pi(x) \propto \sum_n exp(-beta E_n) \psi_n(x) \psi_n(x) Here, the first term to the right is the Boltzmann probability (statistical) the 'psi' term is the Schrödinger term (quantum). That's all there is, let's just not be afraid of quantum physics. It's our daily life. Best greetings from Paris, Werner
